Not sure I would have been President w/o his great talent, loyal help. RIP."{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/05/18/politics/george-bush-roger-ailes-president/index.html|title=Bush 41 praises Ailes, says he's not sure he would have been president without him|first=Eugene|last=Scott|publisher=CNN|date=May 18, 2017}} On August 16, 2017, Bush and his son George W. released a joint statement in which they condemned the violence at the [[Unite the Right rally]].{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/onpolitics/2017/08/16/george-h-w-bush-george-w-bush-we-must-reject-hatred-all-forms/572468001/|title=George H. W. Bush, George W. Bush: We must reject 'hatred in all forms'|first=Jessica|last=Estepa|publisher=USA Today|date=August 16, 2017}} On September 7, 2017, Bush partnered with former presidents Carter, Clinton, George W. Bush, and Obama to work with [[One America Appeal]] to help the victims of [[Hurricane Harvey]] and [[Hurricane Irma]] in the [[Gulf Coast of the United States|Gulf Coast]] and [[Texas]] communities.{{cite news|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/349993-former-presidents-add-irma-recovery-to-fundraising-appeal|title=Former presidents fundraise for Irma disaster relief|last=Shelbourne|first=Mallory|date=September 10, 2017|work=The Hill|accessdate=11 September 2017}} ===Health=== In 1991, ''The New York Times'' revealed that Bush was suffering from [[Graves' disease]], a non-contagious thyroid condition that his wife Barbara also had.{{cite news |last1=Altman |first1=Lawrence |title=In Strange Twist, Bush Is Suffering From Same Gland Disease as Wife |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/05/10/us/in-strange-twist-bush-is-suffering-from-same-gland-disease-as-wife.html |accessdate=June 5, 2018 |work=The New York Times |date=May 10, 1991}} On February 24, 2000, Bush was standing at a reception for 90 minutes when he felt lightheaded. He was admitted to a hospital with an irregular heartbeat.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/02/25/us/the-2000-campaign-ex-president-falls-ill.html|title=THE 2000 CAMPAIGN; Ex-President Falls Ill|date=February 25, 2000|agency=Associated Press}} When Bush was released three days later, his doctors said that he had retained the irregularity in his heartbeat.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/02/27/us/national-news-briefs-elder-bush-is-released-after-more-heart-tests.html|title=Elder Bush Is Released After More Heart Tests|date=February 24, 2000|work=[[The New York Times]]}} On March 11, 2007, Bush fainted on a golf course and was admitted to the Eisenhower Medical Center in [[Rancho Mirage]], but was released the following morning.{{cite news|url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/2007/03/12/Presidents-father-faints-on-golf-course/41821173725180/|title=President's father faints on golf course|date=March 12, 2007|publisher=UPI}} Bush suffers from [[Parkinsonism|vascular parkinsonism]], a form of [[Parkinson's disease]] that has forced him to use a motorized scooter or wheelchair since at least 2012.{{cite web|title=Photo P012712PS-0676|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/whitehouse/6773105167/in/photostream/|date=January 27, 2012|publisher=The Whitehouse|accessdate=April 24, 2013}}{{cite news|last1=Updegrove|first1=Mark K.|title=An Exclusive Conversation with President and Mrs. Bush|url=https://parade.com/123684/markupdegrove/15-george-hw-bush-family-is-what-matters/|accessdate=February 15, 2017|work=[[Parade (magazine)|Parade]]|date=July 15, 2012}} In July 2015, Bush suffered a severe neck injury. At age 91 in October that year, he was wearing a neck brace in his first public engagement since the accident when he threw the [[ceremonial first pitch]] for the [[Houston Astros]] at [[Minute Maid Park]].{{cite news|last1=McAfee|first1=Tierney|title=PHOTO: George H.W. Bush Throws Out First Pitch at Astros Playoff Game in First Public Appearance Since Neck Injury|url=http://www.people.com/article/george-bush-throws-first-pitch-houston-astros-game-neck-injury|accessdate=January 31, 2016|work=People|date=October 12, 2015}} Bush wrote a letter to president-elect [[Donald Trump]] in January 2017 to inform him that because of his poor health, he would not be able to attend [[Inauguration of Donald Trump|Trump's inauguration]] on January 20; he gave him his best wishes. On January 18, he was admitted to the intensive care unit at [[Houston Methodist Hospital]], where he was sedated for a procedure to treat an acute respiratory problem that was stemming from pneumonia.{{cite news|last1=Garcia|first1=Feliks|title=George HW Bush sends personal note to Donald Trump on why he can't attend inauguration|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/george-hw-bush-donald-trump-inauguration-letter-president-attendance-a7534221.html|accessdate=January 18, 2017|work=The Independent|date=January 18, 2017}} Three months later, he experienced a recurrence of pneumonia and was hospitalized.{{cite web|title=Former President George HW Bush hospitalised in Houston|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/04/18/former-president-george-hw-bush-hospitalised-houston/|website=The Telegraph|accessdate=April 19, 2017|language=en|date=April 19, 2017}} On April 22, 2018—the day after his wife's funeral—the former president was hospitalized with a blood infection.{{cite web|url=https://www.dallasnews.com/news/texas/2018/04/23/george-h-w-bush-admitted-houston-hospital-blood-infection|title=George H.W. Bush admitted to Houston hospital for blood infection|date=April 23, 2018|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2018/04/23/george-hw-bush-admitted-hospital-days-wifes-death/|title=George H.W. Bush admitted to hospital days after wife's death|first=Telegraph|last=Reporters|date=April 23, 2018|publisher=|via=www.telegraph.co.uk}} The infection led to [[sepsis]].https://edition.cnn.com/2018/04/23/politics/george-hw-bush/index.html One month later, he was briefly hospitalized again, after experiencing fatigue and low blood pressure.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/05/27/politics/george-hw-bush-hospital-maine/index.html|title=George H.W. Bush Apologizes After Actress Heather Lind Accuses Him of Sexual Assault|work=Newsweek|date=October 25, 2017|accessdate=September 14, 2018}}{{cite news|author= |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/10/26/560148936/george-h-w-bush-acknowledges-groping-multiple-women |title=George H.W. Bush groped her during photo op|website=[[NJ.com]]|date=November 17, 2017|first=Amy|last=Kuperinsky}} === Longevity === On November 25, 2017, Bush became the [[List of Presidents of the United States by age|longest-lived U.S. president]] when he surpassed the 93 years and 165 days lifespan of [[Gerald Ford]], who died in 2006.{{cite news| last=Bowden| first=John| date=November 25, 2017| title=Bush 41 becomes longest-living president in US history| url=http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/361795-bush-41-becomes-longest-living-president-in-us-history | work=The Hill | location=Washington, D.C. | access-date=November 25, 2017}} Bush is currently {{age in years and days|1924|6|12}} old, and he is the nation's [[Living presidents and vice presidents of the United States|oldest living president as well as the oldest living vice president]]. He is also the first president to reach the age of 94, reaching that milestone on June 12, 2018.{{Cite web |url=http://time.com/5310620/george-hw-bush-first-president-94-years-old-birthday/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=June 27, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614021607/http://time.com/5310620/george-hw-bush-first-president-94-years-old-birthday/ |archive-date=June 14, 2018 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} The [[List of Vice Presidents of the United States by age|longest-lived U.S. vice president]] is [[John Nance Garner]], who died on November 7, 1967, 15 days short of his 99th birthday.{{cite news| last=Lewis| first=Janna| date=January 22, 2009| title=Texans who were presidents, vice-presidents| url=http://www.forthoodsentinel.com/leisure/texans-who-were-presidents-vice-presidents/article_6b538cd2-aa2a-53a2-bc6f-6df30cfadf71.html| work=Fort Hood Sentinel|location=Fort Hood, Texas|accessdate=April 22, 2018}} ==Presidential library== {{Main|George Bush Presidential Library}} [[File:George Bush Presidential Library.jpg|thumb|right|The George Bush Presidential Library on the west campus of Texas A&M University in College Station, Texas]] The George Bush Presidential Library is the nation's tenth [[presidential library]] and was built between 1995 and 1997. It contains the presidential and vice presidential papers of Bush and the vice presidential papers of [[Dan Quayle]].{{cite web |title=The Birth of the Tenth Presidential Library: The Bush Presidential Materials Project, 1993–1994|publisher=George Bush Presidential Library |url=http://bushlibrary.tamu.edu/giq.html |accessdate=March 22, 2007|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070410185146/http://bushlibrary.tamu.edu/giq.html |archivedate = April 10, 2007}} It was dedicated on November 6, 1997 and opened to the public shortly thereafter; the architectural firm of [[Hellmuth, Obata and Kassabaum]] designed the complex. The George Bush Presidential Library and Museum is located on a {{convert|90|acre|m2|adj=on}} site on the west campus of [[Texas A&M University]] in [[College Station, Texas]], on a plaza adjoining the Presidential Conference Center and the Texas A&M Academic Center. The Library operates under [[National Archives and Records Administration|NARA]]'s administration and the provisions of the Presidential Libraries Act of 1955. The [[George Bush School of Government and Public Service|Bush School of Government and Public Service]] is a graduate [[public policy school]] at Texas A&M University in College Station, Texas. The graduate school is part of the presidential library complex, and offers four programs: two master's degree programs (''Public Service and Administration'', and ''International Affairs'') and three certificate programs (''Advanced International Affairs'', ''Nonprofit Management'', and ''[[Homeland Security]]''). The Master in International Affairs (MIA) degree program offers concentrations in either National Security and Diplomacy or International Development and Economic Policy. ==See also== {{Wikipedia books|George H.
